div.head: RUSSIA TO-DAY.
div.p: "How much is this the greatest event in history, and how much the best 1" So exclaimed Charles James Fox in the first enthusiasm of the French Revolution. We do not know whether the Battle of Mukden is likely to be reckoned among the best events in history, but beyond question it is one of the greatest We are not referring merely to the terrific scale of the engagement itself, though nothing to equal it is to be found in the authentic annals of mankind. If we dismiss the half-mythical battles of ancient and mediaeval times, no such hosts of organized and disciplined troops have ever been in action before ; and it may be that neither the hordes of Xerxes, or Genghis Khan, or Tamerlane, or any other of the leaders of armed races, ever left such an appalling multitude of dead and maimed men on a battle-field as that which now strews the blood-stained hills and valley of Manchuria. But it is not only this aspect of the matter which gives the Titanic combat and the whole campaign its unique character. Great battles, if none so great as this, there have been before, and will be again. But perhaps there is no instance on record of an Empire shattered and humbled with such startling rapidity. It has sometimes been said that there is no parallel for the rise of Russia to the first rank among European Powers. Is there any parallel for the swift completeness of its fall t Empire, have been overthrown and have perished in the past; but we can scarcely recall a caw in which the collapse has not been preceded >'? a long period of gradual decadence and a contracted struggle with a steadily growing rival. Egypt, Assyria, Persia, Parthia, came to naught, but it was the work of centuries. Carthage was crushed, but only after generations of struggle and three great wars with a mightier rival. Rome itself forfeited its power eventually ; but the process of decay went on from age to age, and from one widely-separated disaster to another. Spain, which in its arrangement, its haughty pretensions, and its fierce grasp over two continents, was a prototype of Russia, waned away into insignificance ; but not until France and Britain and Holland had been hammering at the huge fabric for two hundred thirty And Russia, till a few months ago, seemed as mighty, as menacing, as impervious to external assault, at any of the world-embracing States of the past. For a hundred and fifty years and more that vast bulk has brooded, enormous and threatening, over Europe and Asia. The history of the eighteenth and ninetenth centuries is largely the history of the rise of the Muscovite Tsardom to ah but the first place in the hierarchy of the nations. From her first emergence out of mere barbarism Russia assumed this haughty hurdle, and it was almost unquestioningly conceded to her. "God has given me power over the nations," was Peter the Great's exulting exclamation. "Russia," said Frederick the Great, "is a terrible Power. In another half century she will be making all Europe tremble." The forecast of the astute Prussian monarch has been fulfilled. Europe has been trembling over Russia ever since. As Metternich said, Russia is a Power hungry-always wanting something more ; and the statecraft of the West has been constantly occupied either in giving Russia what she wanted or endeavoring more or less successfully to keep it from her. The fear of Russia, the dread of that vague and massive force, is the dominant note in all the international politics of the nineteeth century ; and the relations with one another of Great Britain, France, Germany, Austria, and Turkey were deeply influenced by it Russian aggression, Russian ambition, Russian designs, were the perpetual subject for discussion in the cabinets, the chancelleries, and the newspapers ; but nobody hinted a doubt of Russia's power, which went on growing to all appearance greater and more pervasive from year to year. If she was to be arrested on her path, if the momentum of that cosmic force was to be checked, it was not questioned that it would take some almost impossible combination of the other naval and military states to perlorm the task. Such was Russia, and so did Russia tower aloft before the eyes of the world a short twelve months ago. And now, Never could there be a more striking illustration of lines which when Byron wrote them seemed exaggerated enough "A thousand years scarce serve to form a f " [state, An hour may lay it in the dust" So it has been. As things go in the cycle of history, it is but an hour since the hand was raised that has dashed Russia helpless and broken^to the earth. It is no age-long contest, no Thirty Years War, or series of public campaigns, that has crumbled the strength of the Colossus and shivered its feet of clay: and no combination of famous traditional opponents Iim been needed. A single small nation which, before these events, was not even ranked among the leading states of the world, has done the deed. Japan, "little Japan," as we should have said a year ago, struck, and Russia fell. The Great Power of Europe and Asia was revealed as a Great Weakness. Her navy was swept out of existence. Her armies, ill-led and ill-organized, fought bravely enough; but .hey were beaten, again and again, without one single gleam of success, until this last fight has overwhelmed them in irretrievable loss. Russian diplomacy, Russian foresight, Rusian obedience to the Autocracy, the Russian soldiers, the Russian fleets—what are they Unlay 1 So sudden and speedy has been the cataclysm that we can hardly yet grasp its full mowing add importance. As for the possible and prospective results, a volume might be written. But for the moment let us be content to familiarize our minds with the portentous event as strange and significant as anything that has been witnessed for centuries —the swift and tragic overthrow, by a despised and unknown antagonist, emerging, as it were, from a hidden corner of the earth and seas, of the mighty Empire that seemed to hold the fate of Europe and Asia in in insatiable hands,

div.head:
THE RUSSIAN RETREAT
PREPARATIONS TO BE RENEWED. THE RECENT CASUALTIES.

div.p: The Russian retreat continues very slowly. The Japanese, who are worn out, are pursuing feebly. (Havas.)

It is understood here that Kuropatkin prefers to remain in Manchuria, and has accepted the command of the First Army Corps. It is believed that the Russian preparations will be renewed. The mobilization will largely be undertaken, for the purpose of strengthening the position in the event of peace negotiations. The place of origin of Linievitch's dispatches is not disclosed. They are, apparently, comipg from the Sungari, where the forces from Russia are reaching him.(Reuter.)

The revised figures of the Japanese casualties at Mukden are 50,000. The Russian casualties from the commencement of the battle at Mukden to Tieling are estimated at 175,000, including the prisoners. The damage to the bridges is impeding the pursuit and will probably give the Russians time to concentrate and reinforce, and to erect defenses with a view to holding the line from Chaug chun to Kirin. Chang-chun is on the railway due west of Kirin. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE JAPANESE LOAN. ISSUE IN ENGLAND AND U. S. A.

div.p: Baron Takahashi, Vice President of the Bank of Japan, has arrived here. He states that the new loan contemplated will prohably be issued in England and America, but there is reason to believe that the German, Dutob, Swiss, and Belgian banks are all anxious to secure a portion. Nothing has been settled. (Reuter)
M. Mjasojadoff. Governor of Viborg, has been shot by a young man, named Reinikka. The wounds are not dangerous. (Reuter.)
House of Commons.—Lord Percy announced that Colonel Swayne telegraphs that the Mullah has sent a deputation to Berbers and concluded peace. (Reuter.)

France, the United States, and Holland are threatening a coercive action against Venezuela, owing to the latter's drastic treatment of the French and American concessionaires, and the illegal imprisonment of Dutch sailers. (ft)

div.head: ROYAL YACHT STORM-BOUND. A TERRIPIC TEMPEST.

div.p: The Royal Yacht "Albert and Victoria,' with the Queen on board, is storm-bound here, owing to a terrific tempest which is ravaging the Spanish and Portuguese coasts. (Reuter.)
An appalling boiler explosion-has occurred at Brockton (Massachusetts) in a shoe factory. 150 persons, mostly females,-were killed. (R.)
The. Chamber of Deputies has rejected a motion to the-effect that public opinion should be consulted before dissenting the separation vf the Churches from the State, - (Havas)
Foot and Mouth Disease has broken out in the Talkha district, Gharbieh province.
The Brindisi Mail will be distributed at G. P. 0., Alexandria, at 6.30 p.m. today.
A Thunderstorm, accompanied by violent rain, broke over Cairo early yesterday afternoon
Quarantine restrictions are now applied in Egyptian ports against arrivals from Bhavnagar.

div.head: Ministry of Justice.—
div.p: It is announced that the Ministry of Justice has decided to retire that well-known official, Hanna Bey Beaooum.

div.head: Shah's Birthday.—
div.p: A reception was held at the Persian Agency to-day by the Persian Diplomatic Agent, on the occasion of the 55th birthday of the Shah of Persia.

div.head: Gamblino Den Raided.—
div.p: On Monday night the Cairo police of the Esiekieh Kism successfully raided the Lebanon Bar (Fegalla quarter), where gambling was being carried on.

div.head: Cairo Station.—
div.p: The Val *de Travers As- phalts Paving Company has obtained the con- tract from the Railway Administration for asphalting the new goods platforms at Cairo, station,
The "Freres" Case will come before the Mixed Court, Cairo, on the 10th proxo. Maitre. Morpurgo will represent Messrs. Mazeltob and Mansour and Maitre Widal will be counsel for the Freres.
Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Kin Shams and Khalifa quarters of Cairo at dawn on Friday, during the night of Saturday, and at dawn on Sunday, will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: Sudan Mines. —
div.p: The London Stock Ex- change Committee have appointed to-day as a special settling day for Sudan Mines, Limited —7,004 shares of £1 each, fully paid (Nos. 601 to 7,604.
The "Reunion Ramliste" are giving a ball at the Baghdad Hotel, San Stefano, on Saturday next, commencing at 9.30 p.m. A special tram will leave San Stefano for the city after the ball, at 2.60 a.m.

div.head: Asile Rudolph.—
div.p: M. Nioolas Paraskdvay, M. M. Emmanuel Paraskdvay, Mr. Demetrius K Papageorge, and Mr. Policies Anastasiadi have each contributed £1 to the funds of the home in memory of the late George Socolis.

div.head: Army Schools.—
div.p: The Inspector of Army Schools is expected to arrive in Egypt to- morrow. He will inspect the school at Alexandria and be present at the 1st class certificates examination at this station before preceding to Cairo, and afterwards to Khartoum.

div.head: Suez Canal.—
div.p: On the 18th and 19th inst 26 vessels passed through the Canal, 19 of which were British, 1 German, 1 Dutch, 1 French. 1 Greek, 1 Italian, 2 Austrian. The receipts foil the two days amounted to686,177.80 frs.,making the total from the 1st inst. 6,800,430.44 frs.

div.head: Port Said Station.—
div.p: The railway material (track, locomotives, and wagons) which is being used at Port Said for the earthworks of the new railway station, has been entirely supplied by Messrs. Orenstein and Kuppel, Ltd., to the contractors, Messrs. Deyningei and Mikhailidis.

div.head: Train de Luxe.—
div.p: The Board of Administration of the State Railways announces that the daily train "de luxe" running between Cairo, Luxor and vice-versa, will be suppressed from Saturday, 1st proximo. From 2nd April and until further, notice, this train "de luxe" leaving Cairo at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor at 6M p.m., will ran three times a week only, as follows :—From Cairo, every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday; from Luxor, every Tuesday Thursday and Sunday.

"Alexandrie en Baisse" —This "revue" of Mr. George Ralli was-given for the first time last night at the Alhambra Theatre before crowded and fashionable "house." The "revue' is a very smart production and full of top of a allusions and 'hits, which were applauded by the audience, who called the author before the curtain and greeted him with great applause. The dresses and "mise-eo-soene" were very good. A second representation will bc.given this evening, and the "revue" will, it is expected, hold the boards of the Alhambra for many nights to come.

div.head: Victoria Hospital.—
div.p: The report of the Vic- toria Deaconesses' Hospital at Cairo for 1904 shows that 692 sick persons were tended at the. hospital, an A their stay in hospital was 44 days on an average. These patients consisted of 489 men, 147 women, and 56 children, and included, by religions classification, 214 Mus- lems, 150 Protestants, 113 Roman Catholic, 113 Greeks, 49 Copts, 32 Jews, 18 Armenians, and 3 Hindoos. 407 were cured, 138 got better, 62 were not cured, 48 died, and 37 re mained in hospital on January 1. Of the deaths, 7 were of English patients. Of the maladies treated, typhoid heads the list with a total of 72 cases and 8 deaths, but the most fatal malady was bilharzia, with 21 deaths out of 40. Tuberculosis claimed 17 deaths out of 86 cases

div.head: THIRD BALTIC SQUADRON. DUE AT PORT SAID ON FRIDAY.
div.p: Notice has been given to the Suez Canal Company that the Third Squadron of the Baltic Fleet will arrive hereon Friday morning at dawn. I am not yet in a position to give you full details of the composition of this squadron, which is commanded by. Admiral Nqgobatoff, but of the 12 vessels four are battleships, namely "Nicolai I" (flagship), "Admiral Aptaxini," "Admiral Qushakoff," and "Admiral Scuiavin." There is one cruiser of very ancient date, tho "Vladimir Monomak," and three transport, namely, "Livonia," "Kuronia," and "Swire." The hospital ship, "Koetrona,",has join ed this squadron, which also included floating repairing shop in the vessel "Rusenia." This accounts for 1O of the 12 ships com- prising this-squadron, and I-think that in all probability,the other two will be the second- class cruisers "Don" and "Okean" or else the transports "Aiphane" and "Stroganoff" which, according to the Russian papers, are with the fleet. Thirty Russian officers arrived here yester- day by the P. and the S.S "Mongolia" arid are waiting for the Russian steamer to take them to Odessa. They're stopping at the Continental Hotel.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive passed yesterday at Koubbeh. His Highness will invest the newly-appointed Grand Sheikh of Al Azhar University at Abdeen Palace tomorrow. It is stated in a Cairo vernacular newspaper that his Highness has promised to be present at the marriage of Prinee-Guetavus Adolphus of Sweden and Norway and Princess Margaret of Connaught.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA DUNKIRK
div.p: The recent article in the Bulletin of the French Chamber of Commerce at Alexandria in favor of the establishment of a line of steamers between Dunkirk and Alexandria., touching at Havre, St. Nazaire, Bordeaux, Algiers, and Tunis, has aroused much interest in Algiers. The Governor General of Algeria is advocating the scheme, and the Chamber of Commerce of Algiers gas unanimously-expressed a wish-that the French navigation companies should take up the idea and found such a line.

div.head: WARDAN ESTATE COMPANY.
div.p: The meeting of tho Warden Estate Company took place yesterday. The director's report And the accounts were passed, and Mr. D. P. McGillivray, the retiring director, was re-elected unanimously. Messrs. Russell and Kerr, were appointed auditors for the present year. The following .is the text of the speech made by the chairman (Mr. J. W. William- son): Gentlemen, — You have heard the report read by the secretary: there is very little more; that 1 can add to the information contained, therein. Ot the total issued capital of£60,000 a sum of £lO,OOO was paid, in shares, for the purchase of-your Khatatbeh estate. A sum of about £15,600 has been expended on canals and irrigation works. About £18,000 was expended: on buildings, machinery, cattle, wells, leveling of lands. And all working expenses up to the 31st December last, on which date we had a cash balance in the back, of about 13,600. This, together with the new issue of i£5,U00 shares at £6 5s., will-give us a working capital of over £60,000. As most of the necessary building/ and canals are now finished, I consider we have ample lands to bring our undertaking to a successful issue.

div.head: EGYPTIAN TRUST AND INVESTMENT
div.p: A new English company is being formed under the-style of the Egyptian Trust and investment, Limited. Its objects are to carry on trust and financial business in Egypt and the Sudan. We understand that two very well-known local notables are on the advisory board in Egypt, and that Baron de Kussel Bey, 'ate Con trailer General of Egyptian Customs, is to be general manager.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. "Ararat," of the Papayanni Line, left Liverpool yesterday.
The Khedivial Mail SS. "Dakahlieh" will leave Alexandria on Saturday and|Pert8aid on Sunday for Jaffa, Caiffa, Beyrout, Tripoli, Mersina and Alexandretta.

div.head: TURKEY AND EGYPT THE RECENT FRONTIER INCIDENT.
div.p: We are authorised to abate-that on repre- sentation being made by the British and Egyp- tian Governments, the Imperial Ottoman Go- vernment has issued instructions to the Vali of Benghazi to obtain restitution of the camels recently raided from the Aulaid Ali'Sheikh Abdel leader-el Guzza. The camels have now been restored to their owners, and the tribal disturbances are now quietening down, owing to the action of the Ottoman and Egyptian Governments. Negotiations are still proceeding with regard -to the frontier, and the Turkish claims to part of the coast at the Bay of Solum.

div.head: BISHOP BLYTH'S VISIT.
div.p: The Bishop in Jerusalem and the East arrives At Alexandria, from Tantah on Friday, evening and will stay at 6. Museum-street until Monday. On Saturday next (the festival of the .An- nunciation) the services at St. Mark's Church will be as follows 8 a.m. Holy Communion. 5.15 p.m. Adult Baptisms. 6:15 p.m. Shortened 'Evening 'Prayer and the Confirmation of 12 or. 13 candidates Bishop will give the address. At All Saints' Ramleb, there will be a cele- bration of .the Holy Communion at 8 a.m, but the evening service at 6:30 - p.m. will he omitted on account to the confirmation at fit. Mark's Alexandria.

div.head: MUNICIPALITY FOR CAIRO.
div.p: We have received an elaborate disquisition on a scheme "for a municipality-for Cairo, V M. Touasaint Caveri, formerly of the P. W. D. he an essay on a purely academic subject it is not unworthy of perusal, but wish the example of the Alexandria Municipality before his and the recent abolition of Halouan Municipal Commission, it is obvious that a municipality for the capital does not come within the purview of practical politics.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions exprenad within der discussion.

div.head: THE WRECK OF THE "CAIRO."
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF CHE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,Neither the letter of "Navigator":nor the statement of the position of the Ports and | Lighthouses Administration, in pegard to the very severe conitiojams of the International Chamber of Shipping, help to satisfactorily clear ap the highly important questions arising out of the circumstances attending the wreck of the SS. "Cairo." In the scoount published in the Gazette" of Setardey, last of| the official standpoint, not one of the criticians passed by the Chamber of Shipping is answered. Half of the article consists of an elaborate attempt to ignore the existence of that institution-and, to bolster, up the argument; tha ludicrous plea is put forward that its name does not appear in the "Indicateur Egyptian." The remaining portion of the argument consists of a severe lecture to the Chamber on its impertinence in having the audacity bito discuss the matter at all because the affair Jis sub judice.". According to this, no public body should discuss any matter of pnblic, interest, about which a case was entered in the courts until judgment had been finally givenmonths and possibly a year or two:after it had happened-by the Mixed Court of Appeal. The Chamber is then gravely informed that it should confine itself to matters affecting the general interests of the shipping community 19 a whole." In the opinion of coverybody I have discussed the matter with, the case Loft the "Cairo" not only affects the entire shipping community but also concerns the Egyptian public as a whole, and I am much indebted to the Chamber for having the "impropriety-" to use the official expression--of airing its views in the local Press. What the publie want to know is who was responsible for the ten hours' delay in getting to the steamer. "Navigator" states that "the official who is responsible for the port of Alexandria and the interests thereof is the Captain of the Port." If this is so, the Administration ought to publish & plain statement of the case, on behalfot that official, instead of trying to throw dust in the eyes of the public by begging the question. The Chamber of Shipping has made charges of the gravest concern to all who use the port of Alexandria, and the public expect those charges to be rebutted. The public do not care whether the captain of the "Cairo" did or did not use the I published hydrographic instructions for entering by the Boghaz pass, or whether the "Teir el-Mina" should or should not have watertube boilers. What we want to know is whether & passenger and mail steamer that founders within sight of Alexandria can be allowed to remain without any assistance at the meroy of the winds and waves for ten hours and yet for not a single official of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration to be responsible ? Unless the Administration makes & plain and straighforward statement in answer to this question, the public will have only one answer, and if the "official standpoint," as given in Saturday's "Gazette," be correct, the responsibility is obvious. — I am, etę,

div.head: AT SHEPHEARD'S.
div.p: The small dance which took place on Mon day last at Shepbeard's Hotel proved to be a great success. At dinner in the restaurant we noticed a good many well-known people, among whom were Col. FitzGeorge and a party of 4, including Mr. F. Powell; Major Hammastreet and a party of 7, including Call Magill, Lieut-Col. Todd, Major Wilson, Major Bonggau, Major Hardy, and Capt. Morgan Capt. and Mrs. Samman and a party of six Mr. Penniman, with bia family and & party of 8.; Countess de Roydeville at & table of 9, including the Misses Millochea, Gallini Pasha, Comte de Montebello, Baron de Conde, Mr. B. div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mustapha Pasha Pomey will give his annual dinner at the Savoy Hotel on the 4th spuil. Over 100 covers will be laid, the s tatistinde ing the Ministers, the Corps Duplomatique, the Advisors, Under Soprataries of State honds of departments, etc.
Prince. Abmed. Bonad Pashe is.& passenger to Marseilles. by the SS. "Sohleswig," which left to-day, salso were Prince Lynar and Viscountess Southwell.

The Duke and Duchess of Devonshire are paying a visit to Alexandria prior to retuming to Europe. This morning the Duke, accompanied by Consul-General Gould, 1.8.0., visited Victoria College and secured. a hall-holiday for the boys. | Lady Wingate will probably doave dorzu zope by the Austrian Lloyd stemmer on futur day. The Sider will accompanyikaty Wingate from Cairo to Alexandria.
Sir Ernest Cassel is leaving for Europe on the 27th inst.
Valai-Hassan Boy Abadi hamboansappointed A.D.C. to H.H. the Khedive.
Adly Pasha Yaghon gave a dinner at the Savoy Hotel yesterday evening.
Col. J. Magill, -21.D, O.B., 'R .O., Pincipal Medical Officer in tigypt; is-ooming down to Alexandria from Onivo con bursday, on inspection dates.
Kaimakam Borton Bey has been struok off the strength of the Egyptian Army.

Captain E.0.A. Nowoombe, Royal Bugineers, having reported his arrival in Egypt from England, has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army, with the rank of Bimbabhi, and has been posted to the Sudan Govern ment Railways.
Miss Harriet Lassel has been appointed chief nursa at Kasr-el-Aini Happital ata salary of L.E. 168 per annum.
Mr. Jean C. Bally has sent us €2. for the Foundlings' Home, in memory of the late George Socolis.
Dr. Théogènes Akestoridės and M. Léon [Gatinean, dentist, have been anthorised to follow their professions in Egypt.

The following visitors are staying at the Grand Hotel, Khartoum : Major and Mrs. G. 10.Nicol, Capt. Timmins, Mr. Capkey, Mr. and Mrs. Ch. B. Cox, Miss Sonkler, Mr. R. P. France, Mr. W. Hieks, Mr. H. L. Smith, Mr. Sternberg, Miss H. Howell, Mias C. Ross, Mr. Schweiger, Dr. Begun, Mr. Murphy.

div.head: THE LAND BANK OF EGYPT
div.p: M. Canivet a vraimeut la plume malheu- rouse. 11 s'enfonce de plus en plus. Ou peut lire, en effet, dans la n° d'hier de" La Rdforme" :— "L'figyptiau Gazette" affirme qua nous iui avona reprochd d'avoir public un article sur la Land Bank. O'est faux. " Voici oe qua nous avons dcrit:— " Hier "l'Egyptian ftazette" a publid un article tfbs violent contra la Comitd de 1*As- sociation, son prdsident at quelques courtiers de la plaoa. " Vous passaz à ofitd, char confrere. La ques- tion n'astpas da savoir, si la lettra de "l'ludd- pendant" vise certains courtiers ou seulement la ootation de la Land Bank, mais si TEgyp- tian Gazette" a publid un article ou simplement insdrd une lettre. C'dtait le seul point en dis- cussion dnn« notre entrefilet. Ne pouvant nous rdpondre, rous vous Stes raocrochd à une vdtil'e et vous n'avez pas hdsitd à dire: "G'est faux quo nous ayons reproohd à 'TEgyptian Gazette" d'avoir publid un artiole. Voioi ce que nous avons dcrit: Hier "l'Egyptian Gazette" a pu- blid un artiole trfis violent! " C'est de la logique, nouveau style

div.head: Societe Anonyms du Behera ASSEMBLEE GEnERALE ORDINAIRE
div.p: Les recettes de l'annde sesont dlevdea à LR 72,087 et les ddpenseskL.fi. 47,818, laissant un bdndfice net de LR 24.269. En 1895 les recettes ont dtd de LR 37,613 et les ddpenses de LR 25,897 ; en 1899 on a eu 73,195 LR de recettes contre 61,854 LE. de ddpenses. On voit qu'en 1904 on a rdalisd une forte diminution des ddpenses en mfime temps qu'un forte augmentation des recettes. La valour des annuitds en 1904, capital et intdrfits compris, s'est dlevde à LR 75,432.083. l)e oe montant il restait à peroevoir à la fin de Ddoembre la somme de LR 25,314, dont il a dtd encaissd LR 18,554 depuis le commence- ment de l'annde. Une partie du soldo de LR 6,760 qui reate à peroevoir sera indubitable- ment reoouvrde dans le oourant de l'annde ; le reete sera penju en mfime temps que les an- nuitds proohaines. Les intdrfits sur ventes se sont dlevds à LR 37,394 Dragages.— Les dragages ordinairss pour compte du Gouvernement Egyptian ont attaint Mo 424.260, contre Mo 261.675 dragnds en 1903. En dehors de ce travail, il a dtd dragud 42.314 Me au Canal Abbassieh pour le compte de la Compagnie du Canal de Suez. L'entre- prise spdeiale de l'dlargissement du Canal Ibrahimieh a fourni un cube de dragage de Mo 500.000, contre Mo 280.000 faits en 1903; le dragage sera termind au commence- ment d'AvriL Les ateliers de dragage ont fiabriqud des tuyaux et des khassabiehs brevetds, et exdontd divers travaux pour des tiers, ainsi que tout le matdriel d'entretien pour les maohines de la Socidtd, y compris les tuyaux, siphons, khas- sabiehs, etc. PropriSti territorials.— La surface loudeen 1904 dtait de 34,750 feddans pour une somme de LR 13,486, contre 44,224 feddans et LR 22,906 respectivement en 1903. La diminution dans la superficie et la valeur des locations provient de ce que 11,525 feddans louds pour L.R 10,764 ont dtd vendus et consignds aux acheteurs pendant l'annde passde. Les opdrations de perception se rdsument ainsi pour 1904 : Montant figurant au ddbitdes locataires y compris les arridrds de 1903, LR 18,631.412; Montant passd au erddit des loca- taires, LR 17,802.720; Arridrds figurant au ddbit des locataires au 31 Ddcembre 1904, LE. 828.692; Sur ces arridrds, il a dtd per^u ddjk depuis le ler Janvier 1905. LR 211.466. La saison sdfi ou estivale a joui d'une bonne irrigation; mais vers le millieu de Juillet, cette abondance d'eau a cessd subitement et a occtsionnd la perte d'une partie importante de a rdoolte de riz. Li foumiture d'eau pendant e reate de l'annde a dtd gdndralement satis- laisante. Le coton n'a souffert ni du ver ni d'autres maladies et le rendement en a dtd normal. Le bdtail de la Socidtd qui, en 1903, avait dchappd à la peste bovine en a dtd attaint k plusieurs reprises en 1904. La population des domaines de la socidtd continue à s'accroltre lentement, mais d'nne manifire sensiblement progressive. Les frajs de premier dtablissement se rdpar- tissent comme suit en 1904 : Constructions, canaux, drains, routes, etc. LE. 37.279 ; Ni- vellement, oolmatage et amdliorations du sol LR 34.230 ; Service du cadastre LR —.740 ; Achat de machines LE. 18.333 ; Achat do bd- tail LE. 4.089 ; Aohat d'Outils et Mobilier L R 2.538. La Socidtd a effected l'acquisition de trois paires de maohines laboureuses à vapeur aux- quelles il a dtd fait allusion dans le rapport de l'annde dernifire. Bile se propose 1'achat de trois autres paires de machines à vapeur pen- dant l'annde en oours. La Sooidtd a acquis de Menshawi Pacha et Consorts une superficie de 15.840 feddans, moyennant la somme de LR 150,415, payable par trois annuitds dgales. Il Ini reste à verser deux annuitds en 1905 et 1906 s'dlevantk une somme de LR 97,353.750. Les tones aoquises sont situdes dans la Province du Bdhdra, prfis du village d'Atfeh,et assez rapprochdes du Nil. La Socidtd a dgalement achetd à la liquidation de MM, I*kah et Co, une superficie de 1.183 feddans pour LR 23,471.Ces terres se trouvent dans la province de Gharbieh, et avoisinent la propridtd actuelle de la Socidtd à Kom-Wahal. Une troisidme superficie que la Sooidtd a acquise consiste en 200 feddans, sis au village de Bessendilah, aohetds pour une somme de LE. 4,732. Cotte parcelle se trouve entire- ment enolavde dans les terras de la Sooidtd. Des personnes possddant des paroelles dissd- mindea dans le domains de la Sooidtd, ontoon- senti à des dohanges dans le but d'obtenir une homogduditd plus compldte du domains. Le total des ventes effectudes à ce jour est de 37.232 feddans, qui au prix moyen de LR 29 1/4 reprdsentent une somme de LE. 1,093,760. Le paragraphe suivant donne un rdsumd des opdrations de la Socidtd sous le rapport de l'ac- quisition et de la cession de terras pendant la pdriode qui vient de s'dcouleraveo la superficie restant du possession de la Sooidtd à la fin de l'annde 19M4 : La surface appartenant à la Socidtd an ler janvier 1904 dtait de 109.086 feddans ; au 31 ddeembre de la mfime annde, cette surfaoe a atteint 113.050 feddans, soit une augmenta- tion de 3.964 feddans. A partir du 2 du mfime mois, jusqu'k nouvel avis, oe train " de Luxe" par tant du Cairo à 6 h. 30 m. du soir, et de Louxor à 6 h. 80 m. du soir, aura lieu trois fois par semainc seu- lement aux jours auivants:— Du Cairo, chaque Lundi, Mercredi et Samedi; De Louxor, cheque Mardi, Jeudi et Dimanche. div.head: THE COTTON WORM. THE PREMIER'S CIRCULAR.
div.p: Mustapha Pasha Fehmy's circular on the method to be employed in the destruction of the cotton worm deserves to be given at length in English. It is accompanied by a plate, drawn up by the Khedivial Agricultural Society, giving figures of the cotton moth, its pupa, larva, add eggs. The circular re- marks that since its appearance some years ago the worm has done great damage, and instances the destruction of nearly half the crop in the Behera province last year. The best way of combating the pest is to attack the eggs as soon as they are laid, especially in cases where the cotton has begun to form at the beginning of June. If young plants coming up in April are attacked at the moment they come up from the soil the only thing to do is to gather all the cater- pillars that can be found and sow afresh. In June the eggs which are laid by the parent insect on the under side of one or two leaves per plant near the stem in groups sometimes containing 300 ova, should be picked and burnt 'Throwing them into canals and sakjehs is quite useless. Incubation lasts three or four days, and it is of great import ance to pick the leaves as soon as the eggs are laid. After two or three dayB the newly- emerged larve quit the leaf and spread in all directions. They grow rapidly, reaching maturity in from 18 to 22 days, when they drop to the ground and pupate. The pupal (chrysalis) stage lasts from 8 to 10 days. Within 24 to 48 hours of emergence Hie female is capable of laying eggs, and this process occurs thrice in the summer, the first brood emerging in June (we have seen the month in May, by the a ay), the next in July, and the third in August. No risk is run if leaves on which ova have been deposited are picked and burned without delay. Negligent cultivators are the cause of great loss and damage to their more intelligent neighbours— hence the Khedivial decree, the chief provi- sions of which we gave in our issue of Saturday last In cases where the measures given above have been carried out it is necessary to irrigate the cotton rather rapidly some 30 days after the eggs have been laid, when the chrysalis has been 4 or 5 days in the ground In June the bersim, on which the cotton worm also feeds, is all but over: as soon as it has been cut the ground should be ploughed, and, if there has been evidence of the existence of the pest on the bersim, it should be first irrigated. Tho third generation of the cotton moth is most distinctive, since the broods of June and July receive less attention than they deserve, and after the bersim has disappeared all the caterpillars live on the cotton. It is therefore necessary to insist on the importance of ener- getic measures being taken in Juno and recom- menced in July and August. After the promulgation of the decree in- structions will be issued for tho organisation; of a service charged with its administration and with power to take measures against any abuse that may arise from its application. We may remark in this connection that the female cotton moth is attracted by light, and that the destruction of females by this means might be pursued part passed with the campaign against the ova. A lantern reflecting on to a white sheet attracts this and many other moths, which fly against the sheet and can be destroyed by a handy boy. Males are more numerous and should also be destroyed for it takes two to make a caterpillar. The statement in the circular that the moth is a new arrival in Egypt is of some interest if accurate. Stand- ing, whose catalogue of the Palaearctio Lepi- doptem is the standard work on the subject, gives its distribution as follows: Prodenia littoralis. —Crete, Syria, Egypt, Canary Islands, Madeira and Africa in general, Southern Asia, the Malay Archipelago, and Central America. Like most insect pests the moth evidently has an unpleasantly wide distribution!

div.head: THE STATE OPERA SEASON REVIEW OF PERFORMANCES
div.p: It is less easy than it might appear to review this subject ;so many modifications inter vc"c and change any opinion one may form ; so many alternations of good, bad, or indif ferent affect one's idea of each and all the performances. But we must attack our subject: too much excuse argues a weak case. On the whole, it was a disappointing season. To give the worst at once, the repertoire was small, and not varied ; the singers, with one or two exceptions, were not all that we consider Cairo has a right to expect; staging, and chorus, and orchestra were certainly good : there we bad our money's worth. For details we may commence with the conductor. Maitre Zuccani is undoubtedly a musician, and he has his orchestra well in hand; they play in tune and in time; but his forte is climax rather than interpretation, and, most vital point, he sacrifices the voices to the Test. This was proved in Tristan and Mefistofele, the two test operas. Signor Walter, to cite the chief case, has a beautiful voice, but not of that strength one would desire. M. Zuccani, even by merely following his muBio exactly, still more by appropriately modifying certain parts, could have not only shown Signor Walter's voice at its best, but, we claim, would in no way have missed his effects. He overvalues these, and therefore over emphasises them, neglecting the quieter passages in anticipation of the loud and more startling climax, where it may occur or be introduced. For repertoire, we have said that variety and sufficiency was lacking ; for ourselves we modify this by thanking the company for 6ix performances of Mefistofele, one of the greatest Operas ever written. Even we could have welcomed more performances of Tristan and Isolde. True, the presentment was imperfect; but such works as these do not depend upon pre- senitment The rest was mostly Siberia, La Tosco, Fedora, time after time, and far more often than necessary. Here, again, we modify our statement, unfortunately at the expense of the company. Rigoletto, as we have had to avow before, was so bad as to bar a section of the company from appearing in any promi- nence : that naturally excluded all similar operas. In fact, it would seem to us that the whole burden was borne by the three or four principal singers ; and this may largely account for such frequent repetition. Certainly the operas given were interesting, Siberia and La Cabrera especially so; La Tosca showed us how Mile Pandolfini can act; likewise Madame Butterfly and Fedora. For Mefistofele we would refer to our colleague of the "Sphinx" He has evidently taken it as seriously as any one,—perhaps more so— indeed it is far above any of the rest As to the singers themselves, this is a far harder task. We at once state that no per- sonal criticism is intended, and that a critic should, in our opinion, never attack an artiste unless that artiste has failed—or has not tried to use his or her powers adequately. We therefore only blame two of these, viz., the conductor, as before mentioned, who, we think, might have (we are indeed convinced that he could have) thought more of his music than of his "effects," and the light tenor, M. Andreini. M. Andreini has a charming voice, and can and does sing well, and we are persuaded that he could have made Rigoletto a success. We will touch on one other case. Mile. Pinto, the leading soprano, has a fine voice and understands the use of it: why should she, now and again, inflict on us an unwarrantable vibrato ? The death of Marguerite, parts of Siberia, the duets in Tristan, were so admirable and thorough, that we venture to affirm she would have done just as well in those very details which proved sc trying elsewhere. For Mile. Pandolfiui no one has anything but praise : it is a real plea- sure to see such acting, and to listen to such singing. Signor Giraud, to us, seemed really good in Siberia and in La Tosca, and his acting in Tristan was excellent. Signor Bravi has a most charming voice, and as Faust he is at his best. Both these artistes, we must say, have their special parts, and we would not expect or desire perfection in what obviously does not suit them. Signor Nani has a fine big voice; and this again is the same case. Signor Polese also is a clever actor, especially in La Tosca. The rest all show plenty of merit in due proportion. Signor Walter is, next to Signora Pandolfini, the greatest artist of all, but we have already said that his voice had not a fair chance. The impression, produced by this season as a whole, is, in a few words, as follows: the voices were not (with the exceptions of Mile Pinto and Sig. Nani) strong enough for the theatre. This we affirm to be in fact the fault of the theatre in part and that of the conductor. We say that the ensemble did not justify the choice, that however good all concerned may be in their respective theaters, they do not and cannot give us what we should have here. One is reminded of a "team" chosen at hazard, for individual merit, instead of a company, a unity, which should give that adequacy of result demanded by the condi tions. We cite in conclusion, and from neces- sity, not from any idea of controversy with other Cairo papers,—the Verdi Theatre. That theatre was an "Opera Comique," in no way supplanting, but supplementing, our Grand Opera. We do not care to think that com- parison should be needed: each enterprise should stand by itself: and for the Grand Opera to have to avow that the "Verdi" has done better, — even as well — has encountered it on its own ground, is at least illogical. Of course, for such singers as Signa. Svicher, or Signa Bellincioni no such statement cau apply : but surely it should not be necessary to compare the other voices : the Khedivial Opera gives us one side, the "Verdi" an- other if both attempt the same objects.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The change in weather which occurred monday became more pronounced yesterday, when Alexandria was plunged into the depth of winter again. The morning was wet, several heavy showers of rain falling. At noon, there was quite a squall of wind, rain and hail. The afternoon was showery and uncertain and towards the evening the wind rose again. The barometer is now sightly rising.
